questions.text:
Ten days after delivery, a 1500-g (3.3-lb) male newborn is feeding poorly. He was born at 32 weeks' gestation. He has had frequent episodes of vomiting for the past 2 days. He has had no hematemesis or diarrhea. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 45/34 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is distended and hard; there is diffuse tenderness to palpation and rebound. The patient is responsive only to painful stimuli. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.0 g/dL, leukocyte count is 17,900/mm3, and platelet count is 90,000/mm3. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.27


PCO2

51 mm Hg


PO2

55 mm Hg


HCO3-
20 mEq/L


O2 saturation
93%


Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun and a nasogastric tube is placed. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Administration of ampicillin, gentamicin, and metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Removal of an aganglionic colonic segment is the definitive treatment for Hirschsprung disease, for which preterm delivery and male sex are risk factors. Hirschsprung disease can manifest with abdominal distention and vomiting due to constipation, but an abdominal x-ray of Hirschsprung disease would show the absence of gas in the distal colon with a dilated bowel proximally rather than the pneumatosis intestinalis and pneumoperitoneum seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newborn

A massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.

Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

B) CORRECT:

Management of NEC is mainly supportive and includes bowel rest, gastric decompression, antibiotics, and parenteral feeding. If there is evidence of bowel perforation in NEC, surgical intervention is warranted. Surgery should also be considered in patients with findings concerning for bowel necrosis (e.g., peritonitis, shock, acidosis) and/or in those whose clinical features worsen despite supportive treatment. This patient presents with severe symptoms requiring emergency exploratory laparotomy, which will likely include the removal of necrotic portions of the bowel to prevent progression of bowel necrosis, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antimicrobial regimens such as ampicillin, gentamicin, and metronidazole are part of the management of suspected or confirmed NEC at all stages and are appropriate in this patient. However, antibiotics are not the definitive treatment in a patient with metabolic acidosis, peritonitis, and imaging findings of pneumatosis intestinalis and pneumoperitoneum (which indicates bowel perforation and most probably bowel necrosis).

D) INCORRECT:

Supportive care, including bowel rest, total parenteral nutrition, fluid replacement, and cardiovascular or respiratory support, is the initial step in the medical management of uncomplicated NEC (i.e., without perforation or peritonitis). However, supportive care is not the definitive treatment in a patient with metabolic acidosis, peritonitis, and imaging findings of pneumatosis intestinalis and pneumoperitoneum (which indicates bowel perforation and most probably bowel necrosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Barium enema is used in the treatment of meconium ileus, which can manifest with abdominal distention and vomiting. However, abdominal x-ray of meconium ileus shows dilated loops of small bowel above the terminal ileum rather than the pneumatosis intestinalis and pneumoperitoneum seen here. Barium enema plays no role in diagnosis and/or treatment of NEC. Furthermore, exposure to barium may further aggravate the damage to this patient's gastrointestinal tract (i.e., the signs of bowel perforation and most probably bowel necrosis on imaging).
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (with oral contrast; AP view) of an infant with cystic fibrosis

Multiple dilated loops of small bowel are seen. Two loops in the right lower quadrant are opacified with contrast, while others are gas-filled. No gas has passed into the colon. The cause for obstruction proved to be inspissated meconium (not visible) in the distal ileum. An nasogastric tube is present in the stomach.
questions.hint: This preterm newborn's clinical features (e.g., vomiting and lethargy) and abdominal x-ray showing gas within the intestinal wall (pneumatosis intestinalis) suggest necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity (pneumoperitoneum) is consistent with bowel perforation.

questions.text: An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period he has vomited after each of his feeds. He was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz). His feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk-based formula. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 67/min and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; bowel sounds are absent. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 and platelet count is 118,000/mm3. A nasogastric tube is placed. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease can manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and an inability to pass stool secondary to obstruction from an aganglionic portion of the rectosigmoid colon. Failure to pass meconium for > 48 hours and a positive squirt sign further support this diagnosis. If the disease is complicated by enterocolitis, explosive bloody diarrhea is common. This patient developed symptoms > 2 weeks after delivery, which makes another diagnosis more likely. Moreover, an abdominal x-ray of Hirschsprung disease would show an absence of gas in the distal colon with a dilated bowel proximally rather than the pneumatosis intestinalis seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newborn

A massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.

Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

B) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum is the most likely cause of painless hematochezia in children < 2 years old. Patients are often asymptomatic but may present with abdominal pain and hematochezia in case of infection, secondary volvulus, or bowel obstruction due to secondary intussusception. Meckel diverticulum cannot be visualized on a plain abdominal x-ray but requires a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan and is not associated with pneumatosis intestinalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Meconium ileus can present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to ileal obstruction from impacted stool. This diagnosis is suspected when meconium fails to pass within the first 48 hours of life and is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis (∼ 90% of cases). Abdominal x-ray of meconium ileus shows dilated loops of small bowel above the terminal ileum. Although this patient presents with abdominal distention, absent bowel sounds, and vomiting, a diagnosis of meconium ileus is inconsistent with his diarrhea, the x-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis, and the onset of symptoms > 2 weeks after delivery.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (with oral contrast; AP view) of an infant with cystic fibrosis

Multiple dilated loops of small bowel are seen. Two loops in the right lower quadrant are opacified with contrast, while others are gas-filled. No gas has passed into the colon. The cause for obstruction proved to be inspissated meconium (not visible) in the distal ileum. An nasogastric tube is present in the stomach.

D) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to intestinal obstruction from twisting (i.e., volvulus) of the bowel. Bright red blood per rectum may also be present due to intestinal necrosis. Abdominal x-ray may show a coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus. Pneumatosis intestinalis on this infant's x-ray rules out malrotation.

E) INCORRECT:

Cow milk protein allergy (CMA) is the most common food allergy in children and either manifests with symptoms occurring immediately after ingestion of cow milk protein (IgE-mediated), such as anaphylaxis, urticaria, and angioedema, or with symptoms with delayed onset (non-IgE-mediated), such as protein-induced proctocolitis and/or enterocolitis. Infants with protein-induced proctocolitis may present with rectal bleeding but otherwise appear well. Patients with food protein-induced enterocolitis present with diarrhea, severe vomiting 1–3 hours following antigen ingestion, dehydration, and lethargy. An x-ray in protein-induced colitis would show air-fluid levels rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with intussusception typically present with the classic triad of episodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and currant-jelly stool (composed of blood and mucus). While this patient presents with abdominal tenderness, vomiting, and lower gastrointestinal bleeding, he is younger than would be expected for this diagnosis (i.e., children 3-month to 6-years of age) and also does not have a characteristic sausage-shaped abdominal mass. In intussusception, an abdominal x-ray does not show pneumatosis intestinalis, but may reveal a soft tissue mass (typically in the upper right quadrant in children) with proximal bowel obstruction (e.g., air-fluid levels and bowel dilation).
Image Description:

Ultrasound abdomen (bowel; transverse plane)

Concentric alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings are visible. The hyperechoic rings (green overlay) are formed by mucosa and the hypoechoic rings (red overlay) by submucosa. Together the alternating layers produce a target-like appearance (target sign; bull's eye sign).

G) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) can manifest with abdominal distention, severe postprandial, nonbilious, projectile vomiting, and failure to thrive starting 2–6 weeks after birth, but it is not typically associated with diarrhea or hematochezia. Moreover, a palpable, olive-shaped mass is usually present in the epigastrium (hypertrophic pylorus) in patients with HPS. Abdominal x-ray in HPS may show stomach distention only but not pneumatosis intestinalis.

H) INCORRECT:

Duodenal atresia manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios (since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction) but does not cause bloody diarrhea. Abdominal x-ray would also show a double bubble sign rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a newborn with duodenal atresia

A nasogastric tube terminates in the gastric antrum. Gaseous distention of the stomach and pyloric channel (green overlay) and dilatation of the duodenal bulb (red overlay) are seen. Bowel distal to the duodenal bulb does not contain gas.

This appearance has been termed the “double-bubble sign.” This sign is seen with duodenal atresia and several other congenital and acquired causes of duodenal obstruction.

I) CORRECT:

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common cause of acute abdomen in premature infants with low birth weight. It typically occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has begun. Infants present with poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, thrombocytopenia, and/or a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds.

If uncomplicated NEC (i.e., without perforation/peritonitis) is diagnosed, blood cultures, broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and supportive care (i.e., bowel rest, total parenteral nutrition, fluid replacement, and cardiovascular/respiratory support) are the management of choice. Surgical treatment is warranted when there is evidence of perforation (e.g., pneumomediastinum) or no response to optimal medical therapy.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows gas within the wall of the intestine (i.e., pneumatosis intestinalis) and evidence of portal venous gas, which is diagnostic of this condition.

questions.text: A 24-day-old infant girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of fever, vomiting, and diarrhea. She has fed less and has had decreased urine output for 1 day. She was born at 33 weeks' gestation and weighed 1400 g (3 lb 1 oz). Her diet consists of breast milk and cow milk protein-based formula. Examination shows abdominal rigidity, distention, and absent bowel sounds. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows gas within the intestinal wall and the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Duodenal atresia presents with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios (since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction) but does not cause bloody diarrhea or peritonitis (i.e., abdominal rigidity and guarding). Abdominal x-ray would also show a double bubble sign rather than pneumatosis intestinalis. In addition, duodenal atresia is typically associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down syndrome. This patient lacks any dysmorphic features to suggest a chromosomal abnormality.
Image Description:

Ultrasound of a fetus in the second trimester with duodenal atresia

The stomach (S) and proximal duodenum (D) show severe dilatation and fluid collection (resembling two bubbles). Both structures are separated by the pyloric sphincter (green overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

Meckel diverticulum is the most likely cause of painless hematochezia in children < 2 years old. Patients are often asymptomatic but may present with abdominal pain and hematochezia in case of infection, secondary volvulus, or bowel obstruction due to secondary intussusception. Meckel diverticulum requires a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan for visualization; it cannot be seen on a plain abdominal x-ray. Furthermore, it is not associated with pneumatosis intestinalis.

Remember the rule of 2's: Meckel's diverticulum occurs in 2% of the population, usually manifests in the first 2 years of life, has a length of 2 inches, is located 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, and often consists of 2 types of tissue (mostly gastric and pancreatic tissue).

C) INCORRECT:

Meconium ileus can present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis due to ileal obstruction from impacted stool. This diagnosis is suspected when meconium fails to pass within the first 48 hours of life; it is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis (∼ 90% of cases). Abdominal x-ray of meconium ileus shows dilated loops of small bowel above the terminal ileum. Although this patient presents with absent bowel sounds and vomiting, a diagnosis of meconium ileus is inconsistent with his diarrhea, the x-ray findings, and the onset of symptoms > 2 weeks after delivery.

D) INCORRECT:

Cow milk protein allergy (CMA) is the most common food allergy in children and either presents with syndromes occurring immediately after ingestion of cow milk protein (IgE-mediated) such as anaphylaxis, urticaria, and angioedema, or in syndromes with a delayed onset (non-IgE-mediated) such as protein-induced proctocolitis and/or enterocolitis. Infants with protein-induced proctocolitis may present with rectal bleeding but otherwise appear well. Patients with food protein-induced enterocolitis present with diarrhea, severe vomiting 1–3 hours following antigen ingestion, dehydration, and lethargy, but symptoms that suggest peritonitis, such as abdominal rigidity, are uncommon. An abdominal x-ray in protein-induced colitis would show air-fluid levels rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

Symptoms of cow milk protein allergy (CMA) typically resolve following withdrawal of the offending agent.

E) INCORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease can present with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and an inability to pass stool secondary to obstruction from an aganglionic portion of the rectosigmoid colon. Failure to pass meconium for > 48 hours and a positive squirt sign would further support this diagnosis. If the disease is complicated by enterocolitis, explosive bloody diarrhea is common. However, in Hirschsprung disease, abdominal x-ray would show an absence of gas in the distal colon with a dilated bowel proximally rather than the pneumatosis intestinalis seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with intussusception typically present with the classic triad of episodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and currant-jelly stool (composed of blood and mucus). While this patient presents with abdominal tenderness, vomiting, and lower gastrointestinal bleeding (albeit occult, not gross), she is younger than would be expected for this diagnosis (i.e., children 3 months to 6 years of age) and also does not have a characteristic sausage-shaped abdominal mass. In intussusception, an abdominal x-ray would not show pneumatosis intestinalis; instead, it may reveal a soft tissue mass (typically in the upper right quadrant in children) with proximal bowel obstruction (e.g., air-fluid levels and bowel dilation)

Ultrasound is the imaging test of choice for the diagnosis of intussusception. Typical findings are the target sign and the pseudokidney sign.
Image Description:

Transverse view of an abdominal ultrasound in a patient with intussusception showing a so-called target sign: The invaginated portion of bowel (green overlay) resembles rings on a target, where the intestinal walls form the echogenic rings.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) can manifest with abdominal distention, severe postprandial, nonbilious, projectile vomiting, and growth faltering starting 2–6 weeks after birth, but it is not typically associated with diarrhea or hematochezia. Also, a palpable, olive-shaped mass is often present on examination of the epigastrium (hypertrophic pylorus). Abdominal x-ray in HPS may show stomach distention; it would not show pneumatosis intestinalis.

Ultrasound is the diagnostic test of choice in hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and typically reveals an elongated and thickened pylorus.

H) CORRECT:

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common cause of acute abdomen in premature infants with low birth weight. NEC typically occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has begun. Infants present with poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, and/or a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds, all of which are present in this infant. X-ray of the abdomen showing pneumatosis intestinalis confirms the diagnosis of NEC. Other typical x-ray findings include dilated bowel loops, portal venous gas, and abdominal free air in the case of bowel perforation (seen in this case). Bowel perforation requires emergent laparotomy and likely resection of the affected bowel to prevent progression of bowel necrosis, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and shock.

If uncomplicated NEC (i.e., without perforation/peritonitis) is diagnosed, administration of an IV broad-spectrum antimicrobial regimen with supportive care (i.e., bowel rest, total parenteral nutrition, fluid replacement, and cardiovascular/respiratory support) are the management of choice. Serial abdominal x-rays should be conducted every 6 hours to exclude perforation.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a premature neonate

Multiple loops of gas-filled bowel are seen, some of which are accompanied by linear (example indicated by red arrowhead) and bubbly (examples indicated by green arrowheads) lucencies that indicate intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis; areas in green circles). Subtle linear lucencies (examples indicated by black arrowheads) projecting over the right upper quadrant might indicate portal venous gas. There is no pneumoperitoneum.

An NG tube (yellow overlay) terminates in the stomach.

I) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus can present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis due to intestinal obstruction from twisting (i.e., volvulus) of the bowel. Bright red blood per rectum may also be present due to intestinal necrosis. Abdominal x-ray may show a coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus and a kidney bean sign in cecal volvulus; it would not show pneumatosis intestinalis.
Image Description:

The types of volvulus are classified by anatomical location as illustrated here.

- Midgut volvulus: A malrotated midgut causing mechanical bowel obstruction, mostly in neonates and infants. Fibrous peritoneal bands (Ladd bands) attaching the cecum to the retroperitoneum are a common pathological finding in midgut volvulus.

- Cecal volvulus: The cecum rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.

- Sigmoid volvulus: The sigmoid colon rotates on its mesenteric axis resulting in mechanical bowel obstruction and vascular compromise.
questions.hint: Air in the intestinal wall, or pneumatosis intestinalis, is indicative of severe inflammation; air in the peritoneal cavity, or pneumoperitoneum, is suggestive of bowel rupture.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old male infant is in the neonatal intensive care unit for preoperative management while he awaits a Norwood procedure for a hypoplastic left heart. He was born at a gestational age of 39 weeks and 3 days to a 28-year-old gravida 2, para 2 woman via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and there were no complications during or immediately after delivery. He was started on prostaglandin infusion while he is awaiting surgical intervention.
The infant was initially nursing well but stopped eating yesterday and had intermittent emesis. A nasogastric tube was placed yesterday afternoon and now delivers full feeds. During the past 2 hours, the infant has had three episodes of bradycardia with associated oxygen desaturation.
On physical examination, he is initially sleeping but awakens. His anterior fontanelle is open and flat, there is a systolic 3/6 murmur heard throughout his precordium, and femoral pulses are 2+. He has acrocyanosis and cool distal extremities, a normal respiratory rate, clear lungs, a slightly distended abdomen, and hypoactive bowel sounds. The liver edge is felt at the costal margin.
A complete blood count (CBC) reveals an elevated leukocyte count with left shift but is otherwise normal. A basic metabolic panel is unremarkable. A normal cardiac silhouette and clear lung fields are evident on chest radiograph. A paucity of bowel gas is noted on abdominal radiograph.
After stopping his enteral feeds and decompressing his abdomen with a nasogastric tube, what additional next step is indicated in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with ampicillin, gentamicin, and metronidazole
Start nasal continuous positive airway pressure at 6 liters of oxygen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) has been shown to be of benefit in some clinical situations, such as myocarditis, but there is no evidence that administration for neonatal sepsis or NEC is beneficial. Furthermore, this infant is close to full term and is therefore immunologically more mature than an infant born before 32 weeks’ gestation, the point at which maternal antibodies cross the placenta and provide passive immunity to the neonate.

B) CORRECT:

This infant is demonstrating symptoms consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Although premature infants and those weighing <1500 grams at birth are at highest risk for NEC, any infant can develop this condition. Full-term infants who are at greatest risk are those with other underlying conditions that may affect perfusion to the gut (e.g., congenital heart disease, small for gestational age) or weaken the gut barrier, thereby leading to infection (e.g., sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy). The manifestation of NEC may be subtle, as in this case, with episodes of apnea and bradycardia, feeding intolerance, and abdominal distention, or the affected infant may present in shock.

Pneumatosis intestinalis is the classic radiographic finding associated with NEC but does not have to be present for diagnosis. Infants with NEC may or may not have laboratory abnormalities, but if the NEC is severe, laboratory findings will be consistent with intestinal ischemia and shock (including anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyponatremia, and metabolic acidosis).

Given that NEC can progress rapidly, patients with a suspected diagnosis should be treated presumptively, before pneumatosis intestinalis is evident on imaging. Treatment in this patient should include stopping the enteral feeds, decompressing the abdomen using the nasogastric tube or Replogle tube, initiating parenteral nutrition and hydration, and initiating empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics that provide anaerobic coverage. Ampicillin, gentamicin, and metronidazole is a reasonable combination for this purpose.

Key learning point: Treatment for infants with suspected necrotizing enterocolitis includes bowel rest, decompression, and broad-spectrum antibiotics that provide anaerobic coverage.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has hypoplastic left heart syndrome, he has no radiographic signs of heart failure (such as cardiomegaly or pulmonary edema) or hepatomegaly. If the patient did have signs of heart failure, it would be appropriate to administer furosemide and, possibly, to increase the prostaglandin infusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory support may be necessary if this infant develops respiratory compromise related to evolving NEC, but continuous positive airway pressure alone in the absence of gastric decompression is not sufficient treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has hypoplastic left heart syndrome, he has no radiographic signs of heart failure (such as cardiomegaly or pulmonary edema) or hepatomegaly. If the patient did have signs of heart failure, it would be appropriate to administer furosemide and, possibly, to increase the prostaglandin infusion.

questions.text: An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period he has vomited after each of his feeds. He was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz). His feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk-based formula. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; bowel sounds are absent. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 and platelet count is 118,000/mm3. A nasogastric tube is placed. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to intestinal obstruction from twisting (i.e., volvulus) of the bowel. Bright red blood per rectum may also be present due to intestinal necrosis. Abdominal x-ray may show a coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus. Pneumatosis intestinalis on this infant's x-ray rules out malrotation.

Cow milk protein allergy (CMA) is the most common food allergy in children and either manifests with symptoms occurring immediately after ingestion of cow milk protein (IgE-mediated), such as anaphylaxis, urticaria, and angioedema, or with symptoms with delayed onset (non-IgE-mediated), such as protein-induced proctocolitis and/or enterocolitis. Infants with protein-induced proctocolitis may present with rectal bleeding but otherwise appear well. Patients with food protein-induced enterocolitis present with diarrhea, severe vomiting 1–3 hours following antigen ingestion, dehydration, and lethargy. An x-ray in protein-induced colitis would show air-fluid levels rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) can manifest with abdominal distention, severe postprandial, nonbilious, projectile vomiting, and failure to thrive starting 3–5 weeks after birth, but it is not typically associated with diarrhea or hematochezia. Moreover, a palpable, olive-shaped mass is usually present in the epigastrium (hypertrophic pylorus) in patients with HPS. Abdominal x-ray in HPS may show stomach distention only but not pneumatosis intestinalis.

D) INCORRECT:

Duodenal atresia manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios (since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction) but does not cause bloody diarrhea. Abdominal x-ray would also show a double bubble sign rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a newborn with duodenal atresia

A nasogastric tube terminates in the gastric antrum. Gaseous distention of the stomach and pyloric channel (green overlay) and dilatation of the duodenal bulb (red overlay) are seen. Bowel distal to the duodenal bulb does not contain gas.

This appearance has been termed the “double-bubble sign.” This sign is seen with duodenal atresia and several other congenital and acquired causes of duodenal obstruction.

E) CORRECT:

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common cause of acute abdomen in premature infants with low birth weight. It typically occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has begun. Infants present with poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, thrombocytopenia, and/or a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds.

If uncomplicated NEC (i.e., without perforation/peritonitis) is diagnosed, blood cultures, broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and supportive care (i.e., bowel rest, total parenteral nutrition, fluid replacement, and cardiovascular/respiratory support) are the management of choice. Surgical treatment is warranted when there is evidence of perforation (e.g., pneumomediastinum) or no response to optimal medical therapy.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows gas within the wall of the intestine (i.e., pneumatosis intestinalis) and evidence of portal venous gas, which is diagnostic of this condition.

questions.text:
A preterm infant born at 30 weeks' gestation is in the NICU on day 4 of life with abdominal distension, bilious gastric residuals, and guaiac-positive stools. Physical examination reveals tense abdominal distension (see report).


Heart rate
160/min


Temperature
37.0 °C


Oxygen saturation
95%


Abdominal radiograph: Pneumatosis intestinalis
The mother asks about the risk in full-term infants. Which factor is most strongly associated with this infant’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exclusive breastfeeding provides protective benefits against NEC. Breast milk contains immune-modulating factors and bioactive components that promote a healthy gut microbiome and improve intestinal mucosa integrity, reducing NEC risk.

B) INCORRECT:

NEC is primarily seen in preterm infants due to their immature gastrointestinal tract and compromised mucosal barriers. Full-term infants rarely develop NEC, and when they do, it is usually due to other factors like congenital heart disease.

C) CORRECT:

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) primarily affects preterm infants, especially those born before 32 weeks' gestation. The immature gastrointestinal tract in these neonates has an underdeveloped mucosal barrier and reduced immune defenses, increasing susceptibility to bacterial colonization and inflammation. Additionally, the immature vasculature in the bowel can lead to ischemia, further predisposing these infants to NEC. The combination of these factors highlights the strong association between preterm birth and NEC, as the immature gut environment cannot effectively regulate inflammatory responses, leading to intestinal necrosis.

Key learning point: Being a full-term baby is associated with a lower risk of developing necrotizing enterocolitis, which is more common in preterm infants.

D) INCORRECT:

Antenatal steroids promote fetal lung and organ maturation, reducing complications like respiratory distress syndrome and potentially NEC by enhancing tissue maturity. Inadequate steroid exposure is more concerning for NEC risk. Adequate exposure does not contribute to NEC pathogenesis.

questions.text: You are seeing an 18-day-old newborn who presents with a 2-day history of feeding difficulties and diarrhea. During this time, he has vomited after each feed. He was born at 28 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 1100 g. His feeds include breast milk and cow milk-based formula. On examination, there is diffuse abdominal tenderness and absent bowel sounds. Stool testing is positive for occult blood. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 128 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count 12.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count 118 × 109/L (130–380). A nasogastric tube is placed. An abdominal x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malrotation with volvulus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to intestinal obstruction from twisting (i.e., volvulus) of the bowel. Bright red blood per rectum may also be present due to intestinal necrosis. Abdominal x-ray may show a coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus. Pneumatosis intestinalis on this infant's x-ray rules out malrotation.

B) CORRECT:

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common cause of acute abdomen in premature infants with low birth weight. It typically occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has begun. Infants present with poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, thrombocytopenia, and/or a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds.

If uncomplicated NEC (i.e., without perforation/peritonitis) is diagnosed, blood cultures, broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and supportive care (i.e., bowel rest, total parenteral nutrition, fluid replacement, and cardiovascular/respiratory support) are the management of choice. Surgical treatment is warranted when there is evidence of perforation (e.g., pneumomediastinum) or no response to optimal medical therapy.

Key learning point: Necrotizing enterocolitis is a serious gastrointestinal emergency in premature, low-birth-weight infants, presenting with feeding intolerance, abdominal distention, bloody stools, and characteristic pneumatosis intestinalis on abdominal x-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

Duodenal atresia manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios (since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction) but does not cause bloody diarrhea. Abdominal x-ray would also show a double bubble sign rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cow milk protein allergy (CMA) is the most common food allergy in children and either manifests with symptoms occurring immediately after ingestion of cow milk protein (IgE-mediated), such as anaphylaxis, urticaria, and angioedema, or with symptoms with delayed onset (non-IgE-mediated), such as protein-induced proctocolitis and/or enterocolitis. Infants with protein-induced proctocolitis may present with rectal bleeding but otherwise appear well. Patients with food protein-induced enterocolitis present with diarrhea, severe vomiting 1–3 hours following antigen ingestion, dehydration, and lethargy. An x-ray in protein-induced colitis would show air-fluid levels rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) can manifest with abdominal distention, severe postprandial, nonbilious, projectile vomiting, and failure to thrive starting 3–5 weeks after birth, but it is not typically associated with diarrhea or hematochezia. Moreover, a palpable, olive-shaped mass is usually present in the epigastrium (hypertrophic pylorus) in patients with HPS. Abdominal x-ray in HPS may show stomach distention only but not pneumatosis intestinalis.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows gas within the wall of the intestine (i.e., pneumatosis intestinalis) and evidence of portal venous gas, which is diagnostic of this condition.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant born at 30 weeks' gestation presents with a 12-hour history of increased irritability and feeding difficulties. The infant has vomited twice and passed one loose stool with streaks of blood. On examination, the infant appears mildly dehydrated with a moderately distended abdomen that is tender to palpation. Vital signs show mild tachycardia and normal blood pressure. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Start probiotic therapy and resume feeding with diluted formula
Discontinue enteral feeding and insert nasogastric tube
Obtain immediate surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy
Administer oral rehydration solution and monitor for improvement
Obtain abdominal ultrasound to assess intestinal wall thickness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Probiotic therapy is not indicated in the acute management of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). While probiotics have demonstrated benefit in preventing NEC in preterm infants when given prophylactically, they are not part of treatment once NEC develops. Additionally, resuming any enteral feeding during active disease is contraindicated to allow bowel rest and healing.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of feeding intolerance, abdominal distension, and bloody stool in a premature infant strongly suggests necrotizing enterocolitis. The most appropriate initial management step is to discontinue enteral feeding and insert a nasogastric tube for gastric decompression, followed by broad-spectrum antibiotics and parenteral nutrition.

C) INCORRECT:

While surgical consultation should be obtained, immediate exploratory laparotomy is not indicated unless there is evidence of bowel perforation (e.g., free intraperitoneal air on imaging). The initial approach is supportive medical management with bowel rest and antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral rehydration is contraindicated in suspected necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) because it constitutes enteral feeding. The cornerstone of NEC management is bowel rest, which involves stopping all enteral nutrition and providing parenteral nutrition instead.

E) INCORRECT:

While abdominal ultrasound can be a useful as an adjunctive imaging modality in necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) to assess intestinal wall thickness and perfusion, the immediate priority is bowel rest and decompression. Imaging is obtained after initial stabilization measures are initiated.
